segments.text: Hello and welcome to the Slate Political Gavfest.
October 20, 2022, the polls do not look amazing for Democrats' edition.
I'm David Plots.
I'm CityCasts.
I'm in Brooklyn, New York.
I'm in Slate's Brooklyn Studios.
So exciting and I'm not alone.
I'm with none other than Emily Baslon of the New York Times Magazine and Yale University
Law School.
Hello, Emily.
So nice to see you.
John, we miss you.
John was going to be with us, but mysteriously John who lives in New York, John Dickerson
of CBS prime time with John Dickerson, is in Washington, D.C.
I'm so sad not to be with you.
This week, Gavfest listeners, you'll be sustained through the storms and rains of the following
topics.
First, how bad are the midterms looking for Democrats?
Are the polls dire or not?
Then we will talk about the extraordinary Iran protests with Iranian-American writer
Roya Hakakian.
Then we will talk about a critical fight over trans rights in Arkansas and a really interesting
legal case there.
Plus, of course, we'll have cocktail chatter and a reminder, Gavfest listeners, we are
going to be in Atlanta on Wednesday, November 2nd in just two weeks at 7 p.m. at Georgia
Tech's first center for the arts.
Go to slate.com slash Gavfest Live to get tickets to that show.
We love being in Atlanta last time.
We want to continue that trend.
So please join us slate.com slash Gavfest Live to see us at Georgia Tech on Wednesday,
November 2nd.
John, a couple of months ago, Democrats were cautiously optimistic about the midterm
elections.
The gas prices were declining.
Biden and the Democrats had passed some big bills, the inflation reduction act, notably
Republicans were running some atrocious candidates and the Dobbs decision, which the
catastrophic from a policy perspective seemed to be animating women voters.
Now, if the election gets closer, the thing that generally happens in a lot of elections,
the fundamentals are asserting themselves.
Most voters are unhappy with Biden and by extension with Democrats, the Dobbs' enthusiasm
seems to be waning.
What's happening?
What's happening now?
Gravity is reasserting itself.
It's turning out to be in a funny way.
And Matt Galazias, I think, wrote about this on Thursday morning.
If Democrats, let's say Democrats hold the Senate in their bare majority and only lose
eight seats.
So Republicans need to take six to take the House.
So that would be control of the House would go to Republicans.
And that would be a huge political earthquake.
But historically speaking, Democrats, if they only lost, say, eight seats would have
lost far fewer seats than the in-party of the White House loses in the post-World War
II era and when a president of that party is approval rating is below 50%.
Usually, history would tell you they'd expect to lose anywhere between, say, 25 and 35 seats.
So in that context, they would outperform historical expectations.
It would still be a political earthquake.
Why do I say all of that?
Because it reminds us that the historical weight is heavy on the party that controls
the White House.
The policy weight is very heavy, which is when you ask people to say what issues they
care about.
The issues that they say they care about are the economy and inflation.
And on those issues, depending on what poll you look at, the Republican, the generic Republican
candidate has a 20 to 30-point advantage over the generic Democratic candidate.
So those are all regular gravitational forces.
Then you have the fact that the outparty is often more frustrated than the in-party
and is therefore more enthusiastic.
Although in a lot of polls, it shows that the enthusiasm numbers are the same, which
is again a way in which Democrats are pushing against some traditional historical trends.
What's happened recently is in the generic ballot, particularly in the New York Times
poll, in the generic ballot, which is used as a proxy to understand how the parties
will do in the House races, Democrats are ahead in the generic ballot, which is to say
when you ask, would you vote for a generic Republican or a generic Democrat?
People picked the generic Democrat, but now in the most recent version of that poll, they
have picked, they are picking the generic Republican.
So that's another one of those things that's turned.
And then finally, I would just point out that as you mentioned, the abortion enthusiasm
among women post-dobs appears to have waned.
It is not picked in the top tier of things that voters say they care about, nowhere near
as much as the economy and inflation.
And also then in the Times poll, there was some evidence that independent women sample
sizes are a little small.
The sample size was 233 independents in that poll.
And then I think I didn't see what the women was, but if you assume that women are half
of that, it's around 100.
But independent women in September, favorite Democrats by 14 points, now independent women
back Republicans by 18 points.
Republicans have entirely erased the 11-point edge for Democrats among women in the last
month.
So those are all some of the factors for why this gravity is returning.
Emily, that New York Times poll also found that Americans are concerned about the erosion
of democracy, but they don't seem to be voting on it.
So what do you make of the fact that people are not voting on the erosion of democracy
and women may not be voting on jobs and reproductive rights?
So I think one way to think about this is the difference between voting for pocketbook
issues that are pressing right now.
People are really feeling the bite of inflation, and that really is widely felt, versus these
kind of more long-term concerns that to me feel extremely pressing.
But I think to a lot of people feel abstract, if you are seeing your paycheck dwindle and
you can't buy things you want to buy, or you're worried about your economic security
and the medium run, maybe that feels like more of a problem than the idea that somebody,
probably somebody else, might have more trouble controlling their reproductive future, or even
that the democracy is at stake, because it's not at stake right this second, like we're
going to vote.
So in this immediate election, the idea that this one means that you're protecting future
elections and the whole way of life in the United States, I think maybe people feel like
that's overblown and that you have to show them more direct evidence of a threat in order
for them to vote on it.
The problem, of course, being that if the direct threat is really looming, it may be
too late.
It is amazing to me how bad inflation is as a political headwind.
We haven't, because...
It makes sense though, because everybody feels it.
Everyone feels it.
Right?
Like unemployment actually affects a tiny percentage of people.
I feel like, I mean, significant for those people, but relatively small.
I feel like we've talked about this before.
But inflation is for everyone.
Yes.
We all feel it.
Yeah, we all feel it.
And it turns out, and actually, Matt Iglesias made this point, I think in the piece that
John was referring to a second ago, but that it particularly bites at people in suburbs
and far-range suburbs that they drive a lot.
And so those are people who had been trending Democratic because of Trump.
Women especially been trending Democratic because of Trump.
And I think there's a lot of skepticism and irritation because when gas is expensive,
life is a lot more expensive in places like that.
And if you live a life that's fairly insulated from those price swings, like your life is
more urban or you have an electric car, you bike a lot or whatever, it's easy to be kind
of high and mighty that this stuff shouldn't matter to people if you're a liberal and you
feel like there's this screaming emergency going on.
But people's sense of what they can afford and how they feel about their economic security
is important to them.
Yeah.
And it's obviously not just hitting gas.
It's food and rent and all those other things.
Can't help that the headlines from Britain are so bad, right?
The idea that bread is super expensive there.
I know that we don't live in the United Kingdom, but I just feel like that has to have some
sense and these trends do tend to go together as well.
What I'm interested in and which I haven't really been able to tease out of the polls
as much as I'd like is just in terms of benchmarking voter behavior, people clearly say Biden
isn't doing enough about inflation.
But in the last CBS battle ground tracker poll, there was some number of people who said
we understand that this is not the result of Biden administration policies.
But when people say they are unhappy about and prefer the Democrats to the, I'm sorry,
prefer the Republicans to the Democrats on handling the issue of the economy, is it that
they a blame Biden or is it b that they think, you know, Biden had a tough hand, but Republicans
could handle it better or is it some combination?
My expectation is it's some combination of the two.
For those expecting improvement post election with even Republicans control the House and
Senate on the economy, I think they're in for a real disappointment because there's not
a lot that is going to be done through fiscal policy to improve the economic situation
for Republicans control the House and Senate.
Right.
Although in terms of Republican politics, they probably don't care that much because
everyone fights as though the White House is the only thing that matters and Biden will
take the blame if the economy doesn't perk.
One of the things that I found really interesting in some of the polling this week, which I
love your thoughts on, is that our generation, Gen Xers, have swung really significantly
toward the GOP.
Here's the thing that's goofy about that.
And I asked our elections and surveys director Anthony Cervanto about this.
There's a funky way in which that polling breaks out the age cohort.
So it pulls in a whole bunch of boomers and near boomers in that age category.
So when Pew, which does a more finer look at it, it looks like Gen X is actually, so
those who grew up with Clinton and Obama are sort of more liberal and more or vote for
the pick the Democrat over the Republican.
It's the boomers and people either our age or a couple of years older who pick the
Republican.
So Gen X is basically, you'd expect it.
The oldest of Gen X vote like boomers, the younger of Gen X vote like the generation after
it.
I have this creeping fear that our generation is just going to go down as like sucking terribly.
Like I don't know.
You think that's not fair?
No, I was just bringing it.
Why do you think?
Because it's a big of Ted Cruz.
Because we have Ted Cruz.
That's our most prominent Gen X, sir.
Yeah.
Also, I just feel like we're not really leading.
We've always been really anxious and kind of cramped in our aspirations for life.
I don't know.
What have we done?
I haven't really thought this through and I kind of don't believe in generations, but
I'm concerned about it.
Well, our generation actually is tremendous.
If you think about what we've accomplished in business and culture, if you think about
like all of the Google people.
Oh, great.
I do it.
We are going to...
Bezos.
I'm not so confused as well.
Musk is our generation.
Uh-huh.
Yeah, awesome.
Okay.
Yeah, you're making my point for me.
Our accomplishments are tech world, which I'm not convinced to say the world better.
And but Bezos is not.
He's 64 and Gen X starts at 64.
Bezos is 64.
He's not even claimed Amazon, which at least has made consummhes easier.
Bezos is that old?
God.
He's that old.
He looks like he...
Whatever the oil painting is in his attic, because he looks younger and younger as he
gets older.
Can I say one other...
Can I swerve the car back into the road, which is...
We should stop for a moment and think about the Senate because what's...
Despite all the things we've talked about, there is a different story in the Senate.
Traditionally the Senate has been a little more impervious to national trends, although
in this case, of course, voters in our recent poll about Nevada, for example, eight in
ten of the voters on both sides say that their vote is one of the things that is in mind
is control of the Senate.
So that tends to nationalize an election, but often or more often than in the House,
you have senators who can get out from under national trends.
And this election in particular, you have these...
First of all, Democrats are not operating on Republican turf.
They're mostly operating on Biden turf where there are close races.
And also you have these troubled Republican candidates.
So that's why the polls and everything we've talked about beforehand might not apply in
terms of Democrats retaining control of the Senate.
Yeah.
You do stop and think if the Republicans had just nominated some reasonable people in
Georgia, in Pennsylvania, in New Hampshire, in Arizona, they would just not even be having
any kind of conversation right now.
Right.
It's like they gave themselves a big handicap, but it may not in the end be enough to sink
them.
As you know, Gaffes listeners, we do bonus segments for Slate Plus members every week
here on the Gaffes.
And this week we're going to talk about, yay.
That's how I think you pronounce it.
The artist formerly known as Kanye West, who says he's buying the right-wing Sua Rat
Twitter knockoff site parlor.
We will attempt to make sense of this circus.
I have a special announcement for you today.
For a limited time, you can get six months of Slate Plus for just $29.
That is 50% off.
As a member, you'll get no ads on any of our podcasts on limited reading on the Slate
site and member exclusive episodes and segments from shows like Slow Burn and Amicus and
my favorite hang up and listen.
Slate podcasts cover major news events from elections to social issues to historic court
decisions.
Our shows also discuss what makes a song a smash.
They analyze what's going viral and they decode cultural mysteries.
If we have become part of your listening routine, we ask that you support our work by joining
Slate Plus.
Sign up for Slate Plus now at slate.com slash GABVES Plus to access all of Slate's content
and support our work.
Again, that's just $29 for six months through October 28th.
So sign up now at slate.com slash GABVES Plus.
Hi, I'm Janay Desmond Harris, Slate's Dear Prudence.
I'm dropping in to tell you about a special discount offer on Slate Plus.
For a limited time, you can start a subscription for just $5.
That's right.
For just $5, you'll get three months of ad free listening on every Slate podcast, member
exclusive episodes and segments on shows you love like this one, and unlimited reading
on the Slate site.
Best of all, you'll be supporting Slate's independent journalism.
But hurry, this offer in soon.
Get three months for just $5 by signing up today at slate.com slash podcast plus.
That's slate.com slash podcast plus.
We are joined by Roya Hakakian.
Roy is the author of a Beginners Guide to America for the Immigrant and Curious.
She is a poet and a journalist, and she has been one of the most eloquent American voices
about the Masa mini protests that have been roiling Iran.
We have actually not talked about this on the GABVES.
Can you-
Except for I recommended an interview with you.
Okay, but all right.
Can you begin by situating us?
What are the protests that have so roiled Iran for the past month?
What caused them?
What did the protesters seek?
How is the Iranian government responded to them?
The last time I spoke about this, I compared it to the George Floyd protests in the United
States.
And the reason I like that comparison with despite all of its inaccuracies is that if
George Floyd weren't himself, weren't an ordinary American, if he were a political activist
or anyone else.
We would not have had as much sympathy as we did given who he was.
So I think part of what draws people to the case of Vasa Amini is that she was an everyday
woman, that every ordinary Iranian who, you know, maybe entirely apolitical felt so strongly
about the injustice that she experienced.
And she was just coming for a few days to visit the big city, be with relatives, and
go back home.
She has never been political.
So she's not interon to challenge the status quo.
She's not interon to, you know, take off her hijab and challenge the morality police.
So she's interon just, you know, as a tourist, you know, minding her own business.
Now in a lot of the news accounts, we hear that her hijab had slipped off.
Her headscarf was not where it was supposed to be.
A friend of mine who's Kurdish journalist had spoken to her family and says that that
is not the case.
Her hijab was on.
What had happened was that the buttons, the bottom buttons of her Islamic uniform, which
is sort of this baggy, raincoat-like uniform that you have to put on as a woman in Iran
to cover the curves of your body had been left open.
And that is what the morality police picked on.
So you know, if she were a feminist activist, like so many that we have seen in the past
few years, we would say, oh, you know, she took off her hijab because she was trying
to challenge the system, but she wasn't.
And I think the fact that she was just the regular girl, like anybody else's sister or
daughter, and still, despite all that she had done to abide by the laws, she got into
this mess is what enraged everyone.
One of the amazing things about these protests is I understand people are shouting woman-life
liberty with some notion that these frustration about the conditions that women live under
are intertwined into the other problems with civil liberties and freedoms and basic rights
in Iran.
Why is that happening?
Like obviously there's this ground-to-love support.
People are protesting in numbers that we haven't seen in years.
And is it possible that there is enough frustration about women's issues to seed a revolution
here?
It is a revolution.
I mean, in every possible way, this is the closest thing I have ever seen to the events
that I personally witnessed as a kid in Iran in 1979.
This is a revolution.
I think there are two qualities that turn this into a revolution.
One is that the regime has not been able to curb them, to send people home.
And the other is that the protesters have said and have shown that there is nothing
other than the complete overthrow of the regime that will satisfy them.
So people compare this to what happened in Iran in 2009.
In 2009, during what was called the Green Revolution, people came to the street saying,
where is my vote?
That is not what anybody is saying now.
That in 2009 was a conversation with the system.
They were saying, we have a demand.
We believe that our elections were rigged and we want you to do the right thing by us.
This is not what the public is demanding at the moment.
They are saying, we want nothing other than the Supreme Leader, all the system being entirely
removed from power.
Roya, that seems to be a request that the regime wouldn't allow such a request.
We have seen lots of violence as a result.
But what you just said struck me as a demand that is existential for the regime and therefore
it will have to get put down violently.
Do you see any other option?
I don't hear and do not see any sign of compromise.
I think in some ways, if they were smart, they should have compromised in 2009.
That was a missed opportunity because right now, no reformist, no figure from that whole
bygone possibility of what if we could introduce some moderate from within the regime to appease
the protesters.
That could have happened in 2009.
Right now, I am seeing something I have never seen.
People are defacing the images of Ayatollah Khomeini, the founder of Iran's Islamic Republic.
That had never happened at any point in any of the previous demonstrations.
When the demonstrators go as far as they have, it means that people are done with this entire
ideology.
Roya, you met with Tony Blinken, the Secretary of State.
I wonder what tools you think the United States has to help the protesters if we want to deploy
them.
What could we actually do that might have an impact?
Do you think we are deploying them?
No, we are not deploying them.
I am one of those odd Iranians.
I am very optimistic.
I don't go to meet with the Secretary of State thinking that these people want to screw
us.
I was there thinking, oh, look, they are really trying to make conversation and understand
this.
I really do think Secretary Blinken and others who were at that meeting are trying to figure
this out.
I think, however, the problem is that for the last 20 years, everybody in Europe and in
the United States and in our country, the Democrats, especially, have been so wedded
to the idea of JCPOA, to the idea of nuclear negotiations.
To say, forget about nuclear negotiations and, by the way, the people want to overthrow
the regime is just something that I think nobody is psychologically and intellectually
ready for.
I think that unreadiness is what struck me the most in Washington because I also met
with some members of the Senate when I gave a testimony at the Senate Foreign Relations
Committee.
I don't see that our administration at any level has been ready for this.
But I think if they come together and if they can kind of say, okay, we had a plan A, but
obviously plan A is not working, so let's switch to plan B. If they show intellectual
agility, then I think there's a whole host of things they can possibly do.
And I can enumerate them.
I think they can work with the European allies, they can withdraw ambassadors, they can, using
the fact that Iran is sending drones to Ukraine, bear on Iran in a different, under completely
different international conventions that they have been using thus far, to really squeeze
the regime.
Roya Hakakian, thanks for coming on the Gap Fest.
Thank you for having me on.
Whoa, as we were finishing that segment comes news, little is trust is resigned.
That is amazing.
From being Prime Minister of Britain.
Right and Boris Johnson may be in the competition to replace it, which would be incredible.
This week saw the start of a fascinating and critical trial that will probably have a really
large impact on the right of transgender children and their parents to seek medical
care.
Arkansas in 2021 passed a law barring doctors in that state from providing any gender affirming
care, including hormone treatment, puberty blockers and surgery to children in Arkansas,
and also barring doctors from referring patients to doctors and other jurisdictions.
And now for patients and two doctors supported by the ACLU have challenged this law as unconstitutional.
For discriminating against transgender kids and intruding on parents rights and doctors
free speech rights.
And it's really interesting.
Emily, I know you've covered this issue a ton.
What do you, why is this trial important?
I mean, I think, well, first of all, it's extremely important for transgender teenagers
and kids in Arkansas.
There are almost 250 patients at the medical center program that's in the spotlight here.
So in some ways that's a small number, but it's a number that's very important to the
people who are directly affected.
And then I think what this trial suggests to me so far is the utter poisonous nature
of having politics intrude into medical decisions right now.
I mean, it is just terrible to hear about kids who could lose treatment that for them
is life altering and life critical.
And the idea that the state is going to ban treatment, having reported on this, I don't
know anyone who works in this area who thinks that's a good idea.
Nobody.
That doesn't mean there aren't questions about exactly how treatment should work and
whether in some clinics in the US, the guidelines that professional organizations have put
forward are properly followed.
But this place in particular in Arkansas, it's called gender spectrum, seems to be extremely
responsible in the way that it proceeds.
And so there's just this utter mismatch here between potential harm and what the state
is doing.
And it just, this is not what the state should be in the business of getting into the middle
of interfering in these medical decisions.
Can you back up Emily and explain why the state thinks it has a role here and whether
in its claims about its role setting regulations for medical care, it's using something similar
to or not similar at all to what they did in Texas on abortion, which is using the power
over medical regulations to reach beyond that to make sort of larger cultural policy.
Yeah, I mean, I think the similarity is that you have the state interfering for what seemed
to be cynical political reasons in what should be a kind of scientific process of deciding
what the rules and regulations and standards should be for providing care.
So there is a similarity there and it does feel like, you know, right wing legislators
have seized on this because they think it sounds scary and it's a way of courting their supporters.
And it has a really alienating effect.
I mean, some of the testimony this week, Dr. Michelle Hutchinson, who worked at gender
spectrum for a few years, she was talking about how much anxiety levels among kids have gone
up at the clinic where this treatment is being offered and there have been some concerns
about kids threatening suicide.
And you can really imagine, first of all, there's just the direct impact of being afraid
that your own life, your care is going to be taken from you, not for reasons that have
any kind of medical or scientific basis, but because some politicians decided that you
shouldn't have it.
And then also just the stigma of this is so bad for kids to be made to feel that this
thing that they need is something that the state thinks is, you know, harmful and terrible.
It just really does a lot of damage to these kinds of laws.
And yeah, in that sense, there is a parallel with Texas.
I know this doesn't exactly apply, but what are the limits on when parents can not provide
or provide medical care to their children?
Like, is there any limit?
Could a parent deny a child cancer treatment like a 16 year old?
Can they say you cannot get this radiation?
We don't think you should get this radiation.
I think that a child in that sort of circumstance might, if they could figure out how to voice
their concerns and that maybe that would happen for their medical providers, then you might
have a court appoint a guardian for the kid some way to have to adjudicate whether this
medically necessary care was being denied.
But what's happening here is the opposite.
These are kids whose parents have consented to the treatment.
And so that's another way in which you're just interfering in the family dynamic, right?
Yeah, I mean, to me, what's sort of especially, I think, cruel here is that to the extent
there's a scientific debate about, you know, why the number of kids seeking care is rising
and why many more teenagers are identifying as transgender, it is mostly concentrated
in very progressive communities, right?
It's like people I know, people you guys know, it's in blue parts of the country.
This is a very red part of the country in which kids are having to really fight, right?
They're having to get past a lot of stigma and shame in a lot of circumstances to seek
this care to begin with.
Emily, there are also cases somewhat similar in Alabama and Texas where judges have stepped
in the way of local efforts to impose these kinds of regulations.
Do you think that this decision, which is the first case, I guess, at this level of
its kind, will have effects in those other places or do each one of these instances have
to be taken through the courts as they are?
I mean, the technical answer is that Arkansas is in a different part of the federal court
system than Texas and Alabama.
It's under the auspices of the Ace Circuit, U.S. Court of Appeals.
And so that's like a separate track from the federal courts in Texas and Alabama.
However, I think a trial like this is really important for airing the evidence.
And so I think what you get from a trial like this is an airing of the evidence on both
sides and a full record.
It's unlikely that Texas and Alabama are going to produce a different record.
And so the decisions of the courts aren't binding in those other states, but the idea
that we've had judges look at these facts, that these premises, that this law is being
tested and that there's a factual record is very, very important.
I wonder, do you think we're going to be able to bring contemplation and patience back to
this incredibly important and existential issue for so many people?
Or is the politics are just so bad and so poisonous and such an effective culture war
issue for the right that we just can't?
In the short term, I feel really pessimistic about it because it is this cultural weapon
for the right mostly.
And I think in the longer run, we're going to know more.
We're going to have more research from Europe if from nowhere else.
And that will give people a stronger sense of how to proceed.
But in the short run, this does just seem like a really sad kind of political disaster
to me.
Let's go to cocktail chatter.
Emily, we're not going to have a cocktail because it's lunchtime, but maybe we'll have
a pre-unbusy cocktail.
We have a pre-martini lunch.
We'll have a pre-martini lunch.
We'll have a pre-martini lunch.
At 11 o'clock in the morning.
You have such limited ambitions.
All right, fine.
What will you be chattering to me about when we have a three-martini lunch in a few minutes?
I will be chattering about Nora Efron's salad dressing recipe, which is back in the news
because of the gossipy story about Olivia Wilde, movie director, and Harry Styles, Popstar,
who supposedly maybe had an affair.
There was some accusation by a nanny in the Daily Mail and a piece that was taken down
that Wilde made salad dressing or made some salad with dressing for Styles.
And this is part of why Wilde's marriage broke up.
I have no idea whether that is the case and I should not be repeating it, but it is the
setup for Olivia Wilde having posted not only Nora Efron's salad dressing recipe,
but the page from Nora Efron's famous book, Heartburn, about her own divorce in which
this salad dressing recipe plays an important role.
So I am a huge Nora Efron fan.
I think that I have made the salad dressing even before I learned about Nora Efron, but
I've been doing it wrong.
I kind of knew this already.
I put too much vinegar in this.
My husband would be the first to tell you.
I'm very dependent on the salad dressing recipe.
I do sometimes get a little bit bored of it.
So I've been trying lately to make, so I really like making homemade salad dressing,
but it cannot have more than like four ingredients in it.
I am sorry, that is my limit.
And it also cannot involve any machines.
I have to be able to do it by shaking a jar, basically.
So lately I've been trying to make lemon tahini dressing.
I have not really found one, a recipe that I like.
Same with green goddess dressing.
So, gaffes listeners, if you have, let's say, four or five ingredients, fewer is fine.
Four.
David says four is perfect.
I got one for you.
Okay, great.
David, are you going to give us yours?
Because I am hoping that we will also have some people to send them.
But I like your business.
It's olive oil, shallot, dejean mustard, rice vinegar.
Okay, that's close because it still has mustard added to Nora Efron's, but it's a little
different.
I want a few recipes that don't have dejean mustard in them.
That's my big ask.
Anyway, send us your salad dressing recipes.
John, what's your chatter?
I would like to respond first to the gentle lady from New Haven.
First, you all must eat a lot of salads.
I think we just eat boring arugula, which is just oil, lemon, and some salt.
So I feel...
I think that Ann is going to be in salt.
No, I feel like...
I have had dinner at your house with excellent salads.
Well, no.
No, no, no, no.
That's the way I feel about your wide variety of television watching is like...
I feel like we watch like one thing and then that's...
I don't know.

text: Hello and welcome to the Slate Political Gavfest. October 20, 2022, the polls do not look amazing for Democrats' edition. I'm David Plots. I'm CityCasts. I'm in Brooklyn, New York. I'm in Slate's Brooklyn Studios. So exciting and I'm not alone. I'm with none other than Emily Baslon of the New York Times Magazine and Yale University Law School. Hello, Emily. So nice to see you. John, we miss you. John was going to be with us, but mysteriously John who lives in New York, John Dickerson of CBS prime time with John Dickerson, is in Washington, D.C. I'm so sad not to be with you. This week, Gavfest listeners, you'll be sustained through the storms and rains of the following topics. First, how bad are the midterms looking for Democrats? Are the polls dire or not? Then we will talk about the extraordinary Iran protests with Iranian-American writer Roya Hakakian. Then we will talk about a critical fight over trans rights in Arkansas and a really interesting legal case there. Plus, of course, we'll have cocktail chatter and a reminder, Gavfest listeners, we are going to be in Atlanta on Wednesday, November 2nd in just two weeks at 7 p.m. at Georgia Tech's first center for the arts. Go to slate.com slash Gavfest Live to get tickets to that show. We love being in Atlanta last time. We want to continue that trend. So please join us slate.com slash Gavfest Live to see us at Georgia Tech on Wednesday, November 2nd. John, a couple of months ago, Democrats were cautiously optimistic about the midterm elections. The gas prices were declining. Biden and the Democrats had passed some big bills, the inflation reduction act, notably Republicans were running some atrocious candidates and the Dobbs decision, which the catastrophic from a policy perspective seemed to be animating women voters. Now, if the election gets closer, the thing that generally happens in a lot of elections, the fundamentals are asserting themselves. Most voters are unhappy with Biden and by extension with Democrats, the Dobbs' enthusiasm seems to be waning. What's happening? What's happening now? Gravity is reasserting itself. It's turning out to be in a funny way. And Matt Galazias, I think, wrote about this on Thursday morning. If Democrats, let's say Democrats hold the Senate in their bare majority and only lose eight seats. So Republicans need to take six to take the House. So that would be control of the House would go to Republicans. And that would be a huge political earthquake. But historically speaking, Democrats, if they only lost, say, eight seats would have lost far fewer seats than the in-party of the White House loses in the post-World War II era and when a president of that party is approval rating is below 50%. Usually, history would tell you they'd expect to lose anywhere between, say, 25 and 35 seats. So in that context, they would outperform historical expectations. It would still be a political earthquake. Why do I say all of that? Because it reminds us that the historical weight is heavy on the party that controls the White House. The policy weight is very heavy, which is when you ask people to say what issues they care about. The issues that they say they care about are the economy and inflation. And on those issues, depending on what poll you look at, the Republican, the generic Republican candidate has a 20 to 30-point advantage over the generic Democratic candidate. So those are all regular gravitational forces. Then you have the fact that the outparty is often more frustrated than the in-party and is therefore more enthusiastic. Although in a lot of polls, it shows that the enthusiasm numbers are the same, which is again a way in which Democrats are pushing against some traditional historical trends. What's happened recently is in the generic ballot, particularly in the New York Times poll, in the generic ballot, which is used as a proxy to understand how the parties will do in the House races, Democrats are ahead in the generic ballot, which is to say when you ask, would you vote for a generic Republican or a generic Democrat? People picked the generic Democrat, but now in the most recent version of that poll, they have picked, they are picking the generic Republican. So that's another one of those things that's turned. And then finally, I would just point out that as you mentioned, the abortion enthusiasm among women post-dobs appears to have waned. It is not picked in the top tier of things that voters say they care about, nowhere near as much as the economy and inflation. And also then in the Times poll, there was some evidence that independent women sample sizes are a little small. The sample size was 233 independents in that poll. And then I think I didn't see what the women was, but if you assume that women are half of that, it's around 100. But independent women in September, favorite Democrats by 14 points, now independent women back Republicans by 18 points. Republicans have entirely erased the 11-point edge for Democrats among women in the last month. So those are all some of the factors for why this gravity is returning. Emily, that New York Times poll also found that Americans are concerned about the erosion of democracy, but they don't seem to be voting on it. So what do you make of the fact that people are not voting on the erosion of democracy and women may not be voting on jobs and reproductive rights? So I think one way to think about this is the difference between voting for pocketbook issues that are pressing right now. People are really feeling the bite of inflation, and that really is widely felt, versus these kind of more long-term concerns that to me feel extremely pressing. But I think to a lot of people feel abstract, if you are seeing your paycheck dwindle and you can't buy things you want to buy, or you're worried about your economic security and the medium run, maybe that feels like more of a problem than the idea that somebody, probably somebody else, might have more trouble controlling their reproductive future, or even that the democracy is at stake, because it's not at stake right this second, like we're going to vote. So in this immediate election, the idea that this one means that you're protecting future elections and the whole way of life in the United States, I think maybe people feel like that's overblown and that you have to show them more direct evidence of a threat in order for them to vote on it. The problem, of course, being that if the direct threat is really looming, it may be too late. It is amazing to me how bad inflation is as a political headwind. We haven't, because... It makes sense though, because everybody feels it. Everyone feels it. Right? Like unemployment actually affects a tiny percentage of people. I feel like, I mean, significant for those people, but relatively small. I feel like we've talked about this before. But inflation is for everyone. Yes. We all feel it. Yeah, we all feel it. And it turns out, and actually, Matt Iglesias made this point, I think in the piece that John was referring to a second ago, but that it particularly bites at people in suburbs and far-range suburbs that they drive a lot. And so those are people who had been trending Democratic because of Trump. Women especially been trending Democratic because of Trump. And I think there's a lot of skepticism and irritation because when gas is expensive, life is a lot more expensive in places like that. And if you live a life that's fairly insulated from those price swings, like your life is more urban or you have an electric car, you bike a lot or whatever, it's easy to be kind of high and mighty that this stuff shouldn't matter to people if you're a liberal and you feel like there's this screaming emergency going on. But people's sense of what they can afford and how they feel about their economic security is important to them. Yeah. And it's obviously not just hitting gas. It's food and rent and all those other things. Can't help that the headlines from Britain are so bad, right? The idea that bread is super expensive there. I know that we don't live in the United Kingdom, but I just feel like that has to have some sense and these trends do tend to go together as well. What I'm interested in and which I haven't really been able to tease out of the polls as much as I'd like is just in terms of benchmarking voter behavior, people clearly say Biden isn't doing enough about inflation. But in the last CBS battle ground tracker poll, there was some number of people who said we understand that this is not the result of Biden administration policies. But when people say they are unhappy about and prefer the Democrats to the, I'm sorry, prefer the Republicans to the Democrats on handling the issue of the economy, is it that they a blame Biden or is it b that they think, you know, Biden had a tough hand, but Republicans could handle it better or is it some combination? My expectation is it's some combination of the two. For those expecting improvement post election with even Republicans control the House and Senate on the economy, I think they're in for a real disappointment because there's not a lot that is going to be done through fiscal policy to improve the economic situation for Republicans control the House and Senate. Right. Although in terms of Republican politics, they probably don't care that much because everyone fights as though the White House is the only thing that matters and Biden will take the blame if the economy doesn't perk. One of the things that I found really interesting in some of the polling this week, which I love your thoughts on, is that our generation, Gen Xers, have swung really significantly toward the GOP. Here's the thing that's goofy about that. And I asked our elections and surveys director Anthony Cervanto about this. There's a funky way in which that polling breaks out the age cohort. So it pulls in a whole bunch of boomers and near boomers in that age category. So when Pew, which does a more finer look at it, it looks like Gen X is actually, so those who grew up with Clinton and Obama are sort of more liberal and more or vote for the pick the Democrat over the Republican. It's the boomers and people either our age or a couple of years older who pick the Republican. So Gen X is basically, you'd expect it. The oldest of Gen X vote like boomers, the younger of Gen X vote like the generation after it. I have this creeping fear that our generation is just going to go down as like sucking terribly. Like I don't know. You think that's not fair? No, I was just bringing it. Why do you think? Because it's a big of Ted Cruz. Because we have Ted Cruz. That's our most prominent Gen X, sir. Yeah. Also, I just feel like we're not really leading. We've always been really anxious and kind of cramped in our aspirations for life. I don't know. What have we done? I haven't really thought this through and I kind of don't believe in generations, but I'm concerned about it. Well, our generation actually is tremendous. If you think about what we've accomplished in business and culture, if you think about like all of the Google people. Oh, great. I do it. We are going to... Bezos. I'm not so confused as well. Musk is our generation. Uh-huh. Yeah, awesome. Okay. Yeah, you're making my point for me. Our accomplishments are tech world, which I'm not convinced to say the world better. And but Bezos is not. He's 64 and Gen X starts at 64. Bezos is 64. He's not even claimed Amazon, which at least has made consummhes easier. Bezos is that old? God. He's that old. He looks like he... Whatever the oil painting is in his attic, because he looks younger and younger as he gets older. Can I say one other... Can I swerve the car back into the road, which is... We should stop for a moment and think about the Senate because what's... Despite all the things we've talked about, there is a different story in the Senate. Traditionally the Senate has been a little more impervious to national trends, although in this case, of course, voters in our recent poll about Nevada, for example, eight in ten of the voters on both sides say that their vote is one of the things that is in mind is control of the Senate. So that tends to nationalize an election, but often or more often than in the House, you have senators who can get out from under national trends. And this election in particular, you have these... First of all, Democrats are not operating on Republican turf. They're mostly operating on Biden turf where there are close races. And also you have these troubled Republican candidates. So that's why the polls and everything we've talked about beforehand might not apply in terms of Democrats retaining control of the Senate. Yeah. You do stop and think if the Republicans had just nominated some reasonable people in Georgia, in Pennsylvania, in New Hampshire, in Arizona, they would just not even be having any kind of conversation right now. Right. It's like they gave themselves a big handicap, but it may not in the end be enough to sink them. That's slate.com slash podcast plus. We are joined by Roya Hakakian. Roy is the author of a Beginners Guide to America for the Immigrant and Curious. She is a poet and a journalist, and she has been one of the most eloquent American voices about the Masa mini protests that have been roiling Iran. We have actually not talked about this on the GABVES. Can you- Except for I recommended an interview with you. Okay, but all right. Can you begin by situating us? What are the protests that have so roiled Iran for the past month? What caused them? What did the protesters seek? How is the Iranian government responded to them? The last time I spoke about this, I compared it to the George Floyd protests in the United States. And the reason I like that comparison with despite all of its inaccuracies is that if George Floyd weren't himself, weren't an ordinary American, if he were a political activist or anyone else. We would not have had as much sympathy as we did given who he was. So I think part of what draws people to the case of Vasa Amini is that she was an everyday woman, that every ordinary Iranian who, you know, maybe entirely apolitical felt so strongly about the injustice that she experienced. And she was just coming for a few days to visit the big city, be with relatives, and go back home. She has never been political. So she's not interon to challenge the status quo. She's not interon to, you know, take off her hijab and challenge the morality police. So she's interon just, you know, as a tourist, you know, minding her own business. Now in a lot of the news accounts, we hear that her hijab had slipped off. Her headscarf was not where it was supposed to be. A friend of mine who's Kurdish journalist had spoken to her family and says that that is not the case. Her hijab was on. What had happened was that the buttons, the bottom buttons of her Islamic uniform, which is sort of this baggy, raincoat-like uniform that you have to put on as a woman in Iran to cover the curves of your body had been left open. And that is what the morality police picked on. So you know, if she were a feminist activist, like so many that we have seen in the past few years, we would say, oh, you know, she took off her hijab because she was trying to challenge the system, but she wasn't. And I think the fact that she was just the regular girl, like anybody else's sister or daughter, and still, despite all that she had done to abide by the laws, she got into this mess is what enraged everyone. One of the amazing things about these protests is I understand people are shouting woman-life liberty with some notion that these frustration about the conditions that women live under are intertwined into the other problems with civil liberties and freedoms and basic rights in Iran. Why is that happening? Like obviously there's this ground-to-love support. People are protesting in numbers that we haven't seen in years. And is it possible that there is enough frustration about women's issues to seed a revolution here? It is a revolution. I mean, in every possible way, this is the closest thing I have ever seen to the events that I personally witnessed as a kid in Iran in 1979. This is a revolution. I think there are two qualities that turn this into a revolution. One is that the regime has not been able to curb them, to send people home. And the other is that the protesters have said and have shown that there is nothing other than the complete overthrow of the regime that will satisfy them. So people compare this to what happened in Iran in 2009. In 2009, during what was called the Green Revolution, people came to the street saying, where is my vote? That is not what anybody is saying now. That in 2009 was a conversation with the system. They were saying, we have a demand. We believe that our elections were rigged and we want you to do the right thing by us. This is not what the public is demanding at the moment. They are saying, we want nothing other than the Supreme Leader, all the system being entirely removed from power. Roya, that seems to be a request that the regime wouldn't allow such a request. We have seen lots of violence as a result. But what you just said struck me as a demand that is existential for the regime and therefore it will have to get put down violently. Do you see any other option? I don't hear and do not see any sign of compromise. I think in some ways, if they were smart, they should have compromised in 2009. That was a missed opportunity because right now, no reformist, no figure from that whole bygone possibility of what if we could introduce some moderate from within the regime to appease the protesters. That could have happened in 2009. Right now, I am seeing something I have never seen. People are defacing the images of Ayatollah Khomeini, the founder of Iran's Islamic Republic. That had never happened at any point in any of the previous demonstrations. When the demonstrators go as far as they have, it means that people are done with this entire ideology. Roya, you met with Tony Blinken, the Secretary of State. I wonder what tools you think the United States has to help the protesters if we want to deploy them. What could we actually do that might have an impact? Do you think we are deploying them? No, we are not deploying them. I am one of those odd Iranians. I am very optimistic. I don't go to meet with the Secretary of State thinking that these people want to screw us. I was there thinking, oh, look, they are really trying to make conversation and understand this. I really do think Secretary Blinken and others who were at that meeting are trying to figure this out. I think, however, the problem is that for the last 20 years, everybody in Europe and in the United States and in our country, the Democrats, especially, have been so wedded to the idea of JCPOA, to the idea of nuclear negotiations. To say, forget about nuclear negotiations and, by the way, the people want to overthrow the regime is just something that I think nobody is psychologically and intellectually ready for. I think that unreadiness is what struck me the most in Washington because I also met with some members of the Senate when I gave a testimony at the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. I don't see that our administration at any level has been ready for this. But I think if they come together and if they can kind of say, okay, we had a plan A, but obviously plan A is not working, so let's switch to plan B. If they show intellectual agility, then I think there's a whole host of things they can possibly do. And I can enumerate them. I think they can work with the European allies, they can withdraw ambassadors, they can, using the fact that Iran is sending drones to Ukraine, bear on Iran in a different, under completely different international conventions that they have been using thus far, to really squeeze the regime. Roya Hakakian, thanks for coming on the Gap Fest. Thank you for having me on. Whoa, as we were finishing that segment comes news, little is trust is resigned. That is amazing. From being Prime Minister of Britain. Right and Boris Johnson may be in the competition to replace it, which would be incredible. This week saw the start of a fascinating and critical trial that will probably have a really large impact on the right of transgender children and their parents to seek medical care. Arkansas in 2021 passed a law barring doctors in that state from providing any gender affirming care, including hormone treatment, puberty blockers and surgery to children in Arkansas, and also barring doctors from referring patients to doctors and other jurisdictions. And now for patients and two doctors supported by the ACLU have challenged this law as unconstitutional. For discriminating against transgender kids and intruding on parents rights and doctors free speech rights. And it's really interesting. Emily, I know you've covered this issue a ton. What do you, why is this trial important? I mean, I think, well, first of all, it's extremely important for transgender teenagers and kids in Arkansas. There are almost 250 patients at the medical center program that's in the spotlight here. So in some ways that's a small number, but it's a number that's very important to the people who are directly affected. And then I think what this trial suggests to me so far is the utter poisonous nature of having politics intrude into medical decisions right now. I mean, it is just terrible to hear about kids who could lose treatment that for them is life altering and life critical. And the idea that the state is going to ban treatment, having reported on this, I don't know anyone who works in this area who thinks that's a good idea. Nobody. That doesn't mean there aren't questions about exactly how treatment should work and whether in some clinics in the US, the guidelines that professional organizations have put forward are properly followed. But this place in particular in Arkansas, it's called gender spectrum, seems to be extremely responsible in the way that it proceeds. And so there's just this utter mismatch here between potential harm and what the state is doing. And it just, this is not what the state should be in the business of getting into the middle of interfering in these medical decisions. Can you back up Emily and explain why the state thinks it has a role here and whether in its claims about its role setting regulations for medical care, it's using something similar to or not similar at all to what they did in Texas on abortion, which is using the power over medical regulations to reach beyond that to make sort of larger cultural policy. Yeah, I mean, I think the similarity is that you have the state interfering for what seemed to be cynical political reasons in what should be a kind of scientific process of deciding what the rules and regulations and standards should be for providing care. So there is a similarity there and it does feel like, you know, right wing legislators have seized on this because they think it sounds scary and it's a way of courting their supporters. And it has a really alienating effect. I mean, some of the testimony this week, Dr. Michelle Hutchinson, who worked at gender spectrum for a few years, she was talking about how much anxiety levels among kids have gone up at the clinic where this treatment is being offered and there have been some concerns about kids threatening suicide. And you can really imagine, first of all, there's just the direct impact of being afraid that your own life, your care is going to be taken from you, not for reasons that have any kind of medical or scientific basis, but because some politicians decided that you shouldn't have it. And then also just the stigma of this is so bad for kids to be made to feel that this thing that they need is something that the state thinks is, you know, harmful and terrible. It just really does a lot of damage to these kinds of laws. And yeah, in that sense, there is a parallel with Texas. I know this doesn't exactly apply, but what are the limits on when parents can not provide or provide medical care to their children? Like, is there any limit? Could a parent deny a child cancer treatment like a 16 year old? Can they say you cannot get this radiation? We don't think you should get this radiation. I think that a child in that sort of circumstance might, if they could figure out how to voice their concerns and that maybe that would happen for their medical providers, then you might have a court appoint a guardian for the kid some way to have to adjudicate whether this medically necessary care was being denied.
